TextBody:
Hi Liav,

Thank you for contacting Netwrix Technical Support.

It would potentially be helpful to see the trace.log file for this using --log for more information. Also just seeing the output on the report would be usefult to.
 
This check queries the LastLogon attribute from all domainControllers and should output the domain controller name in the report if it was detected on a specific dc (the default behaviour). 
 
If for whatever reason it has fallenback to the previous behaviour it uses LastLogonTimestamp (the replicated version). 
 
If you have actually checked the event logs and cant see anything for the builtin administrator account (The rid -500) account then you may need to check your event logs to ensure that they are logging the correct events.
 
Logic can be seen here for checking the logs https://github.com/netwrix/pingcastle/blob/2d9ab43ba1f4343f5daa983a840a7de08bf28378/Healthcheck/Rules/HeatlcheckRulePrivilegedAdminLogin.cs#L57

Regards,
Ali Asif
Technical Support Engineer
1-949-407-5125 x1
____________________ _______
Cybersecurity That Works for You

6160 Warren Parkway, Suite 100, Frisco, TX 75034
www.netwrix.com

Thank you for your response.

Where can I find the trace.log file?
Also, the output in the report point to 2 domain controllers we have.

Checked the event logs, they are configured to audit logins, and I can see it in the results, but no events for builtin administrator account found.

What else can I check?

Thank you,
Liav

ref:!00D70091pB.!500Qk0InW7e:ref
Subject: RE: Netwrix Support Ticket #428110 -  - Check for Native administrator usage - Question    [ ref:!00D70091pB.!500Qk0InW7e:ref ]

TextBody:
Hello Liav,

Thank you for your patience. 
We have investigated the logs and according to those, the account seems to be in use.



Here are the relevant log sections that show the DC it checked. Then it shows that the computation value is '0' meaning that it detected a 0 days totally as a difference between the generation date (when running the report) and the time of the last logon.

The query below will query the administrator account and return all properties. We are looking specifically at the LastLogon property in PingCastle which is the domain controller specific version (Powershell uses the lastlogontimestamp by default so below query should be accurate to your case):

Get-ADDomainController -Filter "*" | Foreach {
    $DC = $_.HostName
    Get-ADUser -Filter { ObjectSid -eq "S-1-5-21-1644491937-746137067-682003330-500" } -Properties * -Server $DC | 
    Select SAMAccountName, @{ Name = "LastLogonConverted" ; Expression = { [DateTime]::FromFileTime($_.LastLogon) }}, @{ Name = "DC" ; Expression = {$DC}}
    }


Please let us know about your results.


Thank you,


German Kurdyumov
Technical Support Manager
1-949-407-5125 x7016
______________________ _______
Cybersecurity That Works for You

6160 Warren Parkway, Suite 100, Frisco, TX 75034
www.netwrix.com

From: Netwrix Support <techsupport@netwrix.com>
Sent: Wednesday, November 27, 2024 4:40 PM
To: Liav Avraham‏ <Liav.A@willi-food.co.il>
Subject: Check for Native administrator usage - Question [ ref:!00D70091pB.!500Qk0InW7e:ref ]



 

Hi Liav,

Thank you for contacting Netwrix Technical Support.

It would potentially be helpful to see the trace.log file for this using --log for more information. Also just seeing the output on the report would be usefult to.
 
This check queries the LastLogon attribute from all domainControllers and should output the domain controller name in the report if it was detected on a specific dc (the default behaviour). 
 
If for whatever reason it has fallenback to the previous behaviour it uses LastLogonTimestamp (the replicated version). 
 
If you have actually checked the event logs and cant see anything for the builtin administrator account (The rid -500) account then you may need to check your event logs to ensure that they are logging the correct events.
 
Logic can be seen here for checking the logs  https://github.com/netwrix/pingcastle/blob/2d9ab43ba1f4343f5daa983a840a7de08bf28378/Healthcheck/Rules/HeatlcheckRulePrivilegedAdminLogin.cs#L57

Regards,
Ali Asif

www.netwrix.com

ref:!00D70091pB.!500Qk0InW7e:ref
Subject: RE: Netwrix Support Ticket #428110 -  - Check for Native administrator usage - Question    [ ref:!00D70091pB.!500Qk0InW7e:ref ]

TextBody:
ref:_00D7091pB._500Q000InW7e:ref

Hello German,

Thank you for the quick response!
I'm trying to figure out where is the administrator account is used, but I have double checked and it's not being used for at least a week.
There is no services, opened sessions or any software that use this account.

Also, I tried to search for event ID 4624 and found nothing in both DC servers.

[cid:image001.png@01DB44F8.3B784EC0]

However, whenever I run the query you mentioned, I get the same time as the query started.
Also, I found out the LastLogonTimestamp value is about a week ago, but the LastLogon value is now...
I really don't understand what is going on.

[cid:image003.png@01DB44F8.9221FA00]


Thank you,
Liav

From: Netwrix Support <techsupport@netwrix.com>
Sent: Monday, December 2, 2024 6:41 PM
To: Liav Avraham‏ <Liav.A@willi-food.co.il>
Subject: RE: Netwrix Support Ticket #428110 - - Check for Native administrator usage - Question [ ref:!00D70091pB.!500Qk0InW7e:ref ]

Hello Liav,

Thank you for your patience.
We have investigated the logs and according to those, the account seems to be in use.

[cid:image002.png@01DB44F8.3B784EC0]

Here are the relevant log sections that show the DC it checked. Then it shows that the computation value is '0' meaning that it detected a 0 days totally as a difference between the generation date (when running the report) and the time of the last logon.

The query below will query the administrator account and return all properties. We are looking specifically at the LastLogon property in PingCastle which is the domain controller specific version (Powershell uses the lastlogontimestamp by default so below query should be accurate to your case):

Get-ADDomainController -Filter "*" | Foreach {
    $DC = $_.HostName
    Get-ADUser -Filter { ObjectSid -eq "S-1-5-21-1644491937-746137067-682003330-500" } -Properties * -Server $DC |
    Select SAMAccountName, @{ Name = "LastLogonConverted" ; Expression = { [DateTime]::FromFileTime($_.LastLogon) }}, @{ Name = "DC" ; Expression = {$DC}}
    }


Please let us know about your results.


Thank you,


German Kurdyumov
Technical Support Manager
1-949-407-5125 x7016

Cybersecurity That Works for You

6160 Warren Parkway, Suite 100, Frisco, TX 75034
www.netwrix.com<http://www.netwrix.com>

This check queries the LastLogon attribute from all domainControllers and should output the domain controller name in the report if it was detected on a specific dc (the default behaviour).

If for whatever reason it has fallenback to the previous behaviour it uses LastLogonTimestamp (the replicated version).

If you have actually checked the event logs and cant see anything for the builtin administrator account (The rid -500) account then you may need to check your event logs to ensure that they are logging the correct events.

ref:!00D70091pB.!500Qk0InW7e:ref
Subject: RE: Netwrix Support Ticket #428110 -  - Check for Native administrator usage - Question    [ ref:!00D70091pB.!500Qk0InW7e:ref ]

TextBody:
Hello Liav,

The difference between LastLogonTimestamp and LastLogon is that the first one is replicated version of the latter, it replicates between DCs every 14 days which explains why you have it showing 25/11. LastLogon is not replicated so it shows the most recently updated value only on the DC that authenticated the logon. Our product is looking at LastLogon attribute to report the most accurate data.

I may recommend to look for logon events on that one DC that has the most recent LastLogon attribute value. You may find more info in this MS article: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/archive/technet-wiki/22461.understanding-the-ad-account-attributes-lastlogon-lastlogontimestamp-and-lastlogondate

Let me know if you have any further questions.

Thank you,


German Kurdyumov
Technical Support Manager
1-949-407-5125 x7016
______________________ _______
Cybersecurity That Works for You

6160 Warren Parkway, Suite 100, Frisco, TX 75034
www.netwrix.com

I really don't understand what is going on.

 



 

 

Thank you,

Liav

Get-ADDomainController -Filter "*" | Foreach {
    $DC = $_.HostName
